comments.body:
I see little purpose in this. The bot won't care (since it will both be setting the status and doing the merge only if the status would be set) and if humans are doing things wrong we need to 'discuss' with the humans. When the build breaks and we have a 1-liner to fix it I WANT a human to be able to just push it.

If we want/need a munger which flags those cases where someone merged something by hand, we can do that, but I'd really like to not prevent people from doing useful things in a timely manor (and slapping their wrists if they mess up)

@eparis I'm not sure there's a way to satisfy what you want and what this proposal is trying to do. We specifically don't want all committers to be able to hit the "big green button" on any part of the codebase. Maybe a way to deal with the emergency situation you described (which I think is a legitimate point), is to ensure that the oncall has OWNER permission for the entire codebase for the entire duration of their oncall shift, so there's always someone oncall to merge emergency stuff.

Is the problem people hitting the big green button or people LGTM things which they maybe didn't know enough to LGTM? Today the big green button and LGTM are basically the same. I feel like the 'big green button' we should solve socially, and the latter we should solve with OWNERS.

We can create a report/munger which tracks the PRs where people hit the 'big green button' which could occasionally/regularly be reviewed. If someone regularly is hitting the merge button and shouldn't be, they don't deserve write/merge/push privs....

> Is the problem people hitting the big green button or people LGTM things which they maybe didn't know enough to LGTM? Today the big green button and LGTM are basically the same. I feel like the 'big green button' we should solve socially, and the latter we should solve with OWNERS.

Well, it addresses both.

But I think I understand your proposal: OWNERS should apply to adding LGTM label, but all committers should be able to hit "big green button" but that should be logged and audited.

That doesn't sound particularly unreasonable to me assuming the auditing facility is reliable and secure. But I'm not sure what Brendan or others think. (Or if there's some loophole I'm not considering.)

Just to put numbers to the discussion. `git log --merges --format="%an" v1.1.0..HEAD | sort | uniq -c` This is all of the people who clicked the big green button between 1.1.0 and HEAD. The people at the bottom are the 'owners' who I assume would be exempt from this enforcement.

I'm not sure what these are telling us. But maybe it is telling us we need to start the social engineering now   :)
